sections.title: ğŸŒ³ Core Identity
sections.content:
Common Name: Neem
Scientific Name: Azadirachta indica
Family: Meliaceae
Order: Sapindales
Type: Evergreen medicinal tree
Origin: Indian subcontinent
Other Names: Nimba, Margosa, Indian Lilac

sections.title: ğŸ§¬ Full Botanical Classification
sections.content:
Kingdom â€” Plantae
Clade â€” Angiosperms
Clade â€” Eudicots
Order â€” Sapindales
Family â€” Meliaceae
Genus â€” Azadirachta
Species â€” indica

sections.title: ğŸ” Field Identification Guide
sections.content:
Tall evergreen tree with wide crown
Leaves made of many small pointed leaflets
Leaflets have serrated edges
Bitter taste (traditional test â€” not required to try)
Small white fragrant flowers in clusters
Smooth green fruits turning yellow when ripe
Dark, rough, cracked bark
Strong medicinal smell from crushed leaves

sections.title: ğŸ“ Morphology
sections.content:
Leaves: Compound pinnate, 20â€“40 cm length, 8â€“18 leaflets per leaf, lance-shaped with toothed margin, bright to dark green
Flowers: White, sweet fragrance, small size, axillary clusters, spring to early summer flowering
Fruits: Oval drupe, green â†’ yellow when ripe, contains single seed
Bark: Brown to gray, rough and fissured, bitter taste

sections.title: ğŸŒ Habitat & Growing Conditions
sections.content:
Tropical & semi-tropical climate
High heat tolerance
Moderate to low rainfall areas
Grows even in poor soils
Full sun preferred
Very high drought tolerance
Can live many decades

sections.title: ğŸ§ª Chemical Compounds
sections.content: Azadirachtin (natural insecticide), Nimbin, Nimbidin, Nimbolide, Gedunin, Salannin - These give Neem its antibacterial, antifungal, insect-repelling, and anti-inflammatory properties

sections.title: ğŸ’Š Medicinal Applications
sections.content:
Used Traditionally For: Skin infections, acne & eczema, wound healing, fever support, gum disease, digestive cleansing, fungal infections
Modern Herbal Uses: Antimicrobial extracts, dental care products, skin care formulations, anti-lice treatments, herbal pesticides

sections.title: ğŸ¦· Neem in Dental Care
sections.content:
Neem twigs used as natural toothbrush (datun)
Antibacterial effect on gums
Used in herbal toothpaste
Helps reduce plaque bacteria
Very important student point for traditional oral hygiene

sections.title: ğŸ› Agricultural Importance
sections.content:
Neem is extremely important in organic farming
Natural pesticide source
Neem oil spray controls insects
Neem cake used as soil amendment
Eco-friendly pest control
Does not harm beneficial insects as much as chemical pesticides
Very exam-friendly important point

sections.title: ğŸ§´ Commercial Products
sections.content: Soaps, shampoos, face wash, mosquito repellents, herbal medicines, toothpaste, skin creams, hair oils, organic pesticides

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Ecological & Environmental Benefits
sections.content:
Provides dense shade
Survives harsh climates
Supports birds & insects
Reduces need for chemical pesticides
Helps sustainable agriculture
Good avenue tree
Urban pollution tolerant

sections.title: âš  Safety & Toxicity Notes
sections.content: Neem oil should not be swallowed directly. Excess internal consumption may be harmful. Pregnant women advised caution with neem extracts. Always use medicinally under guidance. (Adding safety notes makes your page more scientific.)

sections.title: ğŸ›• Cultural & Traditional Importance
sections.content:
Considered sacred in Indian culture
Leaves used in festivals
Hung at doors during epidemics traditionally
Associated with purification
Mentioned in Ayurveda texts

sections.title: ğŸ“š Neem in Ayurveda
sections.content:
Classified as: Bitter (Tikta rasa)
Cooling effect
Blood purifier (traditional classification)
Used in skin and metabolic disorders (Ayurvedic context)

sections.title: ğŸ§  Student Quick Facts
sections.content:
1. Called 'Village Pharmacy Tree'
2. Every part is medicinal
3. Source of natural pesticide
4. Used for dental hygiene
5. Highly drought resistant
6. Contains azadirachtin compound
7. Over 100 medicinal uses documented

plants.name: SAPTAPARNI TREE
plants.tagline: The Blackboard Tree - Night-Fragrant Medicinal Wonder

sections.title: ğŸŒ³ Core Identity
sections.content:
Common Name: Saptaparni / Blackboard Tree / Devil Tree
Scientific Name: Alstonia scholaris
Family: Apocynaceae
Order: Gentianales
Type: Evergreen ornamental & medicinal tree
Origin: Indian subcontinent & Southeast Asia
Other Names: Dita tree, Milkwood Pine, Chatim (Bengal)

sections.title: ğŸ§¬ Full Botanical Classification
sections.content:
Kingdom â€” Plantae
Clade â€” Angiosperms
Clade â€” Eudicots
Order â€” Gentianales
Family â€” Apocynaceae
Genus â€” Alstonia
Species â€” scholaris

sections.title: ğŸ” Field Identification Guide
sections.content:
Tall, straight trunk with dense rounded crown
Leaves arranged in whorls (usually 4â€“7 leaves from one point)
Thick, leathery leaves with smooth edges
Milky latex exuding when cut
Small greenish-white fragrant flowers
Long paired cylindrical pods (fruit)
Smooth grey bark

sections.title: ğŸ“ Morphology
sections.content:
Leaves: Simple, whorled arrangement (4â€“7 per node), oblong to lanceolate, thick and leathery, dark glossy green
Flowers: Greenish-white, small, strongly sweet fragrant (especially at night), terminal cymes, autumn flowering (Octoberâ€“November)
Fruits: Long slender cylindrical follicle pods (up to 30â€“60 cm), numerous seeds with silky hairs for wind dispersal
Bark: Grey to brown, smooth to slightly rough, produces milky sap when cut, bitter taste

sections.title: ğŸŒ Habitat & Growing Conditions
sections.content:
Tropical & subtropical climate
Thrives in warm climates
Moderate rainfall preferred
Well-drained soils
Full sun to partial shade
High urban tolerance (common roadside tree)
Lifespan: Several decades

sections.title: ğŸ§ª Chemical Compounds
sections.content: Echitamine, Alstonine, Scholaricine, Ditamine - Important alkaloids contributing to antimicrobial activity, antimalarial properties, anti-inflammatory effects, and antipyretic (fever-reducing) action

sections.title: ğŸ’Š Medicinal Applications
sections.content:
Traditional Uses: Treatment of fever, malaria support, respiratory disorders (asthma, bronchitis), digestive disorders, skin diseases
Modern Uses: Alkaloid-based research compounds, anti-microbial extracts, herbal formulations for respiratory health

sections.title: ğŸ« Educational & Historical Importance
sections.content:
Wood used to make traditional blackboards (hence 'Blackboard Tree')
Lightweight wood used for packing cases and pencils
Planted near schools and institutions
Very important exam point for students

sections.title: ğŸ› Ecological & Environmental Importance
sections.content:
Excellent avenue tree
Provides dense shade
Attractive ornamental foliage
Night-fragrant flowers attract pollinators
Helps reduce urban heat
Urban pollution tolerant
Fast-growing
Soil stabilizer
Supports bird life

sections.title: ğŸ§´ Commercial Uses
sections.content:
Traditional medicine preparations
Timber (lightweight wood products)
Ornamental landscaping
Ayurvedic formulations

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Environmental Benefits
sections.content:
Urban pollution tolerant
Fast-growing
Soil stabilizer
Supports bird life
Improves roadside greenery

sections.title: âš  Safety & Toxicity Notes
sections.content: Contains potent alkaloids. Excess internal consumption may be toxic. Should be used medicinally under expert supervision. Milky latex may cause mild skin irritation.

sections.title: ğŸ›• Cultural & Traditional Importance
sections.content:
Sacred in some Indian traditions
Leaves associated with spiritual symbolism
Known as 'Chatim tree' in Bengal
Often planted near temples and schools

sections.title: ğŸ“š Saptaparni in Ayurveda
sections.content:
Rasa (Taste): Bitter (Tikta)
Effect: Cooling
Traditionally used for fever and respiratory disorders

7. Produces milky latex when cut

options: Wood was used to make traditional blackboards
quiz.answer: Wood was used to make traditional blackboards

4. Requires full sunlight for growth
5. Used in shipbuilding, furniture, and flooring
6. Important forestry and plantation species
7. Golden-brown wood becomes more valuable with age
8. Contains tectoquinone and lapachol compounds

quiz.question: What chemical compounds in Teak wood make it naturally resistant to termites and decay?
